entry.title: Re: SAP S4/HANA Cloud Public, G/L account hierarchy 1799...
entry.content:
Hello @rekafulop 

If FSV 1799 is already created and assigned, but the Balance Validation still fails in J58, it generally indicates a mismatch between what the validation rule expects and what your FSV structure contains.

Check the settings below in the system

1. Full General Ledger account coverage in the FSV

  • GR/IR clearing accounts
  • Bank subaccounts and interim clearing accounts
  • Tax receivables/payables
  • Foreign currency valuation differences
  • Technical clearing accounts
  • Retained earnings & P&L carryforward accounts
    • In Manage Financial Statement Versions, ensure all balance sheet related G/L accounts are linked to nodes in 1799, including.
    • Any unassigned account with a non-zero balance will skew the equation.

2. Node type and sign consistency

    • Assets must be set as debit, Liabilities/Equity as credit (per standard SAP FSV logic).
    • If sign settings in the report variant are reversed from the validation rule, with credits shown as positive, the totals will appear mismatched.

3. Ledger and currency scope alignment

    • Run the validation for the same ledger and currency type used in your reporting local currency and group currency.
    • Make sure balance carry forward and all period-end closing activities are run for that ledger and currency.

4. Retained earnings linkage

    • Verify the retained earnings account is correctly included under Equity in 1799.
    • If omitted, Liabilities + Equity will be short by the net income amount.

5. Variant using FSV 1799

    • In the Balance Validation configuration, confirm the variant is pointing to FSV 1799, not the source FSV you copied from.
    • After copying, check that node types (Assets/Liabilities/Equity) stayed intact.

How to quickly identify the gap

Run G/L Account Balances Display for the same ledger/currency/period as J58.

Export the list of accounts and compare it to the account assignments in 1799.

Any non-zero balance account missing from the FSV should be added.

If the variance equals net income, check the retained earnings mapping.

Once all general ledger entries are correctly assigned and the signs are consistent, the J58 balance validation should succeed without any discrepancies.

Let me know if it works

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Embedded RSSD compatibility and performance
entry.content:
Can you mix RSSD and eRSSD in the same replication domain? Yes

A couple caveats:

  • eRSSDs and routes; from the Repserver Admin Guide: You can create a route from a Replication Server with ERSSD, as long as both the source and the destination servers are version 15.0 or later
  • eRSSDs and standalone access; the eRSSD is shutdown when the repserver is shutdown; if you need to access the eRSSD while the repserver is down you'll need to either a) manually start the eRSSD (see startup command in the repserver's errorlog) or b) load a backup/copy of the eRSSD into a standalone SQLAnywhere database.

As for potential performance issues when using an eRSSD ...

  • regardless of whether you're using an eRSSD or RSSD, the repserver is constantly reading from, and writing to, the (e)RSSD; this means you'll want to insure the (e)RSSD is sitting on a fast (disk) device ... just like you would for any (production) database; since the repserver's stable queues (aka disk partitions) should be sitting on a fast (disk) device I typically place the eRSSD's data/log in its own directory on the same filesystem that contains the repserver's stable queues (see the rs.rs_erssd_database_dir and rs.rs_erssd_tranlog_dir settings in a rs_init resource file)
  • as for the daily volume of 15GB, how fast you can replicate that data is going to be based primarily on a) how the repserver is configured and b) the performance of the physical components, ie, cpus, memory, network, and disks (stable queues, (e)RSSD)

----------------------------

See this Q&A: Is there a method / what are steps to move from using RSSD to ERSSD in Replication Server  for a couple ideas on converting from RSSD to eRSSD. [Obviously run thorough testing before implementing in production.]

entry.title: Re: Automatically Start Sybase Database and SAP Application on the Same Host
entry.content:
FWIW ...

The backup server does not rely on the ASE dataserver so you could start the backup server right away (in the background) without needing to wait for the ASE dataserver to become available.

--------------------

While a hard coded 120-150 seconds of sleep is probably sufficient most times before starting the SAP application, there is a chance that a lengthy recovery operation (during ASE dataserver startup) could take more than 120-150 seconds; in this scenario the 'ps | grep | grep | grep' pipeline will show the ASE dataserver is up but the SAP application, upon starting, would find that its database(s) is not (yet) available.

A more accurate method for determining if the ASE dataserver is available would be to verify that the SAP application's database(s) is online.

One approach would be an isql script that issues the following 2x commands for each database the SAP application relies on:

  • use <sap_application_db_name>
  • select db_name() (should return <sap_application_db_name>)

An alternative approach would be to monitor the ASE dataserver's errorlog watching for messages of the format:

  • Database '<sap_application_db_name>' is now online.

The isql approach is probably simpler and would require a looping construct (eg, 5 second sleep on each pass through loop; after X passes if SAP application database(s) is not online then perform normal error/alerting steps).  The errorlog monitoring approach would be a tad more involved in that you would probably need a couple processes, one process to continuously tail/monitor the errorlog and one process to loop checking for results from the 1st process and then error/alert after X passes if the 'is now online' message(s) is not seen.

--------------------

A further refinement might see a separate service for the backup server,  the ASE dataserver, and the SAP application.  'course additional details like service ordering and dependencies would be required.

entry.title: Re: PCR valuation basis issue
entry.content:
Your system seems to be configured to have only 2 decimals, and SAP will usually round every number before the multiplication/division.

Could you create a Custom Valuation Basis that would be 100 times (or 1000 times) the "real" value so that you could then divide the result of PCR X115 by 100 (or 1000) or replace PCR X115 by Custom PCR Z115 that would incorporate a division by 100 (or 1000) before it's Output?

We've often used this work around, specially when the value of a Constant (in T511K) required more than 2 decimals.

entry.title: Re: RSH - Inable de change the navigation link of the wor...
entry.content:
Hello @RahmaLay 

In SAP S/4HANA Public cloud, the navigation links in the Work Details panel of the Resource Scheduling (RSH) dashboard are controlled by intent-based navigation in the Fiori Launchpad, not by direct configuration in SPRO.

To modify the link so it opens the IW32 Web GUI tile or its Fiori equivalent, Change Maintenance Order, follow the supported method:

  • Determine the semantic object and action associated with the Work Details link. Then, in the Launchpad Content Manager, set up a custom target mapping using the same semantic object and action, but direct it to the IW32 Web GUI app.
  • Place this target mapping in a custom catalogue and assign it to the business roles for your users.

When the user has both the standard and custom mapping, the system will use your custom mapping and launch IW32 instead. But if IW32 is not accessible as a Web GUI application within your Public Cloud scope, an alternative is to map it to the provided Fiori app for maintenance changes orders.

This method guarantees the change is upgrade-safe and adheres to Public Cloud extensibility rules, as direct modification of the delivered RSH app is not supported.

Kind regards,

Chuma Ofole

entry.title: Re: Service Order: Connection between service product and...
entry.content:
Hello @snigdhodeep 

You’re correct about the 42 CAD. It derives from the activity type rate linked to the cost center and activity type (SV01) combination. In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, there is no mandatory service product associated with activity type SSCUI mapping; instead, the connection is indirect through the operation on the service order.

How the cost is determined

  1. Service order item → operation (from the service profile/template).
  2. Operation → activity type like SV01, defaulted via work center/control key/task list
  3. Activity type + cost center → planned price (maintained in Fiori).
  4. Planned cost = activity qty × activity price → shown as ongoing/baseline planned cost.

You can maintain/inspect rates here:

  • Edit Prices for Activity Types – Cost Centers (KP26) – planned prices per cost center and  activity type.
  • Manage Cost Rates – Services (optional) – service-order-specific rates; if maintained, they can drive planned cost.

A quick way to verify in your tenant

  1. Open your service order → Operations tab → check Activity Type (likely SV01).
  2. Open Edit Prices for Activity Types – Cost Centers and display the cost center + SV01 plan price for the relevant period, you should see 42 CAD.
  3. If you also manage Cost Rates – Services, verify whether a service-specific rate is set; if it is, that could be the source.

Let me know if it helps

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Delete ariba CA SES in SAP MM
entry.content:
Hello @pratik_soni6 

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud or On-Premise integrated with Ariba Commerce Automation (CA), suppliers cannot directly delete Service Entry Sheets (SES) created through Ariba from backend tables (SE16N). Doing so is unsupported and may lead to serious data inconsistencies.

Key points to focus on for your case:

• Since the SES originates from Ariba CA, it follows the external approval and posting process.

• If no Material Document was created, and it remains in approval pending status, you can cancel it using the Manage Service Entry Sheets Fiori app (Public Cloud) or ML81N (On-Premises), provided you have the correct authorisations.

• If the approver user has left the organisation, reassign the workflow task to an active user via My Inbox – Workflow Administration or the Workflow Administration app.

• When workflow reassignment is not possible, the SES must be rejected in Ariba and resubmitted, which will withdraw it from SAP.

• Direct table deletion is never advised or supported (even in SE16N) because SES data is linked to follow-on documents and workflow logs.

Check this SAP Documentation KB0399151 - How do I cancel/ delete a service sheet as a supplier? 

Let me know it if helps

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: What does this error mean in ISLM?
entry.content:
Hello @Mithun_Kr 

The error message in ISLM (Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management) titled "Error occurred while creating model specification" is a generic front-end notification indicating that the system was unable to generate the model definition based on the parameters you provided.

How to troubleshoot

  1. Check the ST22 short dumps and SM21 system log immediately after reproducing the error, as the backend dump often contains the precise cause.
  2. Use transaction ISLM_ADMIN → Application Log to see detailed error logs for model creation.
  3. In HANA, review the trace files for _SYS_AFL calls — failures here will often indicate column not found, data type not supported,
  4. Validate datasets with a simple SELECT * in HANA to ensure all fields exist and have expected datatypes.

Field descriptions

These are documented in the SAP Help Portal for ISLM and APL:

  • Training Dataset → Table/View with historical data, including the target you want to predict.
  • Apply Dataset → Table/View where you want to apply the trained model to make predictions.
  • Target → Column in the Training Dataset you want to predict.
  • Keys → Columns that uniquely identify each record in the dataset (must be in both Training and Apply datasets).
  • Key Fields for Parameters → Columns used to parameterise scoring (e.g., document number, item number).


ISLM for Predictive Scenarios – SAP Help Portal
Automated Predictive Library (APL) – SAP HANA Academy

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Ariba - SLP and Buying and Invoicing - are there WSDL...
entry.content:
Hello @anasazii 

Yes, SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance, Buying and Invoicing support web service-based integration for master data with other ERPs. This allows automated, secure, and frequent data exchanges that are much more efficient than manual CSV uploads.

Key Points to note for SOAP Web Services / WSDLs:

  • Ariba provides SOAP-based web services for core master data objects like suppliers, company codes, cost centers

  • Each service publishes a WSDL, allowing you to automate integrations from virtually any ERP or middleware platform.

  • You can access and generate WSDLs via Ariba Integration Manager in the application’s administration section.

  • For steps: Go to Core Administration > Application Integration > Web Services. Select the required service to generate/download its WSDL.Web Services Overview-SAP Help 

Integration & Monitoring:

  • Schedule regular data pushes like every 5 minutes) to Ariba using supported web services.

  • Integration status and error logs can be monitored through Ariba Integration Manager’s dashboard and reports.

  • Alternatives to SOAP:

    • Master Data Native Integration (MDNI): Often used for XML-based data pushes via SAP Integration Suite for batch master data loads.

    • API Business Hub: For some scenarios, REST/OData APIs may exist for required master data objects—check SAP’s API Business Hub for released endpoints.

Best Practice:
Wherever possible, automate master data transfers using Ariba’s web services and avoid manual CSV uploads. Frequent and programmatic integration ensures data quality and up-to-date information.

If you share the specific master data object such as supplier, GL account I can help locate the exact service and integration documentation for your use case.

For more information and references,check below documentation

 How do I generate a WSDL file for an Ariba Web Services task? 

Let me know if you have any further questions

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: How to Synchronize Production Order Dates Back to Net...
entry.content:
Hello @mlasya85 

In standard SAP, network activity dates in PS do not automatically update when linked production order dates change. The PS–PP integration functions as follows:

1. Standard behaviour

  • Assigning a material component to a network activity passes the activity’s requirement date to MRP.
  • MRP creates a planned or production order, which PP schedules forward or backwards from that date.
  • Changes to production order dates do not push back to the network activity automatically.

To update them, use the Transfer Dates function:

  • Transactions: CN22 / CN24 / CN29 (or equivalent Fiori app)
  • Menu: Edit → Dates → Transfer → From Orders
  • This copies the basic/actual dates from the order into the network activity.

2. S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition

  • Use the Update Network from Production Orders app or the Mass Change Project Dates functionality.
  • The production order and activity must be linked via the material component assignment and pegging element.
  • There is no continuous auto-sync, updates are done manually or via scheduled jobs.

3. Do you need to sync these dates?

  • Yes – If project milestones, billing, or dependent activities rely on actual shop-floor dates, syncing keeps the project plan realistic.
  • No – If PS dates are used only for initial planning and execution is tracked in PP separately, syncing may add unnecessary overhead.

4. Recommendation

  • In ETO or long-lead manufacturing, many companies run date transfers on a periodic basis (daily/weekly) so PS reflects actual PP schedules.
  • If supported, automate via a background job or incorporate into your MRP-to-PS update process.

SAP Help Portal – Transferring Dates Between Networks and Orders 

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Why Does SAP B1 Allow Backdated Delivery Without Inve...
entry.content:
Hello @aec-mis 

SAP B1 allows this because negative inventory checks work in real-time, not on historical dates.
When you post a backdated delivery, the system looks at current stock (after later receipts), so it passes—even if stock was zero on that posting date.

With Moving Average, backdated issues use the current cost (possibly zero), then revalue automatically after later receipts.

To prevent it:

  1. Remove Allow Stock Release Without Item Cost
  2. Block backdated postings in Document Settings
  3. Use Transaction Notification SQL to reject deliveries that would cause negative stock on the posting date

Reference: SAP Help – Negative Inventory in SAP Business One

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Integration of Sales Order Scheduling w/o sales order...
entry.content:
In your case, what went wrong is when the sales order was changed (e.g., quantity increase or new item), an order-based FU was created. This behavior is tied to advanced TM license features, which you're trying to avoid.

Why this happens is because SAP uses the control key to determine whether TM-based scheduling should occur. However, if you don’t assign the control key to the sales order type, SAP lacks a clear trigger to apply TM scheduling. This can lead to inconsistent behavior—especially when changes are made after delivery creation.

The BPS schema is assigned to the control key, and the control key should ideally be linked to the sales order type or document category to ensure consistent scheduling behavior.

Below are the recommended approach

  • Assign the control key to the sales order type even if documentation says it's optional. This ensures SAP knows when to apply TM scheduling.
  • Use a logistics integration profile that explicitly disables order-based FU creation. This helps prevent the system from slipping into advanced TM behavior.
  • Monitor changes to sales orders after delivery creation. SAP may re-trigger scheduling logic that defaults to order-based FU creation unless tightly controlled.
  • Use the TRS Test Cockpit to simulate and validate scheduling behavior before applying changes in production.

You can explore more about this setup in SAP’s official documentation on Sales Order Scheduling Based on TM Durations here

entry.title: Re: Supplier and Purchasing group email not picked in PO...
entry.content:
Ok let us see one by one of your issue

Sender email address context is PURCHASINGGROUP

In the Output Parameter Determination app, when context is set to PURCHASINGGROUP, SAP expects a BRF+ expression to resolve the purchasing group code (e.g., 004) into an actual email address. To fix this, create a BRF+ Procedure Call or Decision Table that uses the purchasing group code as input, Returns the correct email address from master data. If you skip this, SAP will treat the code as the email and fail.

Receiver email address context is SUPPLIER

Same logic applies here. When context is SUPPLIER, SAP needs a BRF+ expression to convert the supplier code (e.g., 200025) into the supplier’s email address. To fix this, create a BRF+ Procedure Call or Decision Table that uses the supplier code as input and returns the email address from the Business Partner master data (Communication section)

If I maintain email address directly in Output Parameter Determination app, it works perfectly. Issue occurs if context is maintained as PURCHASINGGROUP.

This confirms that the BRF+ context resolution is missing or misconfigured. To fix this, instead of hardcoding the email, define a BRF+ expression that dynamically resolves the purchasing group code to its email. This allows automation without manual entry.

If I maintain email address directly in Output Parameter Determination app, it works perfectly. Issue occurs if context is maintained as SUPPLIER.

Again, this points to missing BRF+ logic. To fix this, create a BRF+ Procedure Call that accepts supplier code, reads email from Business Partner master data and returns it to Output Parameter Determination

entry.title: Re: How to migrate VV33 in Migrate cookpit
entry.content:
The Migration Cockpit template “Condition records for pricing” is designed for pricing conditions (e.g., discounts, surcharges), not output conditions like those in VV33. These output condition types (e.g., RD00, BA00) are stored in NAST and related tables, and they’re governed by output determination procedures, not pricing procedures.

The error you're seeing—where the condition type isn’t found in T685A; makes sense because T685A is for pricing condition types, not output types. Output condition types are maintained in T685B and T682, and they follow a different logic.

To migrate VV33 (output condition records), you should not use the pricing condition template. Instead use a Custom Migration Object. Create a custom object in the Migration Cockpit or LSMW that targets table NAST or uses function module RV_CONDITION_COPY with appropriate parameters for output conditions.

You’ll need to map Application (e.g., V3 for billing), Output type (e.g., RD00), Partner function, Medium (e.g., print, email), Timing, Language and Communication parameters. VV33 is just a view on the output condition records. The actual data is stored in tables like TNAPR, NAST, and T685B. You can extract the existing records using SE16N or a custom report, then prepare them for upload.

If you’re on S/4HANA, consider using the BRF+ Output Management framework instead of classic NAST-based output. Migration here would involve configuring BRF+ rules rather than uploading condition records.

entry.title: Re: SAP Datasphere Automation : Creating Database user in SAP Datasphere using Datasphere CLI &&
entry.content:
Hi @leenaG ,

Yes they can do both DDL and DML. DML only if they have write data privilege enabled. You can manage the access via the below objects in the JSON. 

"consumptionWithGrant" -> Allow the database user to grant read access to the space schema to other users

"spaceSchemaAccess" -> Grant the database user read access to the space schema

"scriptServerAccess" -> Grant the database user access to the SAP HANA Cloud machine learning libraries.

"localSchemaAccess" -> Grant the database user write access to the OpenSQL schema

"hdiGrantorForCupsAccess" -> Grant the database user read access to HDI containers associated with the space.

Regarding the logs, you can enable the audit logs for each db user by the JSON property "isAuditPolicyActive".  To review the logs you can check the table AUDIT_LOG under DWC_AUDIT_READER.

entry.title: Re: SAP Datasphere Replication Flow Logs: Monitoring & Insights
entry.content:
Hi @yashcp and @joscha_tilgner , I also faced this issue and resolved it with the below steps. The DigiCertGlobalRootCA is missing in datasphere security section due to which its not able to validate the connection to HANA DB of datasphere tenant. To resolve this, i performed the following actions

1. Go to hana cockpit and open the certificate store.

2. Search for DigiCertGlobalRootCA and select the certificate that ends with CA_PXXID. 

3. show the .pem and save it in your device. 

4. Upload the same file in the system-> security tab of your datasphere tenant. 

After this the connection will be working.

entry.title: Re: Bank charges in SAP B1
entry.content:
Hi @user2001 

To enable you handle bank charges correctly in vendor outgoing payments, I suggest you consider the following steps:

First, you should ensure you have correctly defined who pays the bank charges. If the company pays, then the company bears the bank fees separately. If Vendor pays, then deduct the bank charges from the payment amount to the vendor.

Then you need to set up appropriate G/L accounts, then maintain a Bank Charges Expense account in your chart of accounts.

When the company pays the charges, then you are required to:

Post the full invoice amount to the vendor.

Post the net payment amount of bank charges to the bank.

Post bank charges separately as an expense.

When the Vendor pays the charges, then you are required to:

Post the vendor invoice amount as usual.

Ensure to deduct bank charges from the payment amount. Which means you pay less to Vendor.

Then post the deducted bank charges as an expense.

You should configure payment program or manual entries:

Ensure your payment process captures bank charges either during payment run or via subsequent bank statement posting.

Make sure you maintain automatic account determination for bank charges if supported.

Ensure you perform test payments for both scenarios to confirm correct accounting impact.

This approach will ensure your financial postings accurately reflect who bears the bank charges and maintains clear accounting records.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Manage Workflow for Supplier Invoice – Authorization...
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I followed SAP Note 2804158 – Configuration of Flexible Workflows for Supplier Invoices, and it worked successfully in our system. To summarize what the note guided me through:

  1. Defined workflow scenarios for WS00800251 (blocked invoices) and WS00800303 (parked-as-complete invoices) via SAP NetWeaver Gateway.

  2. Activated those scenarios under Flexible Workflow settings.

  3. Set up task names and decision options in Fiori My Inbox (e.g., “Release of Blocked Invoice”).

  4. Linked triggered events to these flexible workflows and deactivated the standard workflows.

  5. For S/4HANA 1809+, registered the Value Help Service for the “Manage Workflows for Supplier Invoice” app.

Result: The flexible workflows are triggered correctly for both blocked and parked complete invoices, and the standard workflow logic is bypassed as expected.

Additionally, I want to highlight a related gotcha: an obsolete workflow (WS08900002) can still be active and cause unexpected workflow triggers even when flexible workflows are disabled. If you encounter this, you can deactivate it via SWETYPV or PFTC by removing its Type Linkage flag—for reference, see KBA 3235839.

entry.title: Re: Registration unit of Billing Document from Service Co...
entry.content:
Hello @ISoma 

As Dequan already mentioned, in the Create Billing Documents app, you can use the Billing Settings option to create a separate billing document for each item on the billing due list and set it to ON. This ensures that instead of merging items into a single billing document when the payer, billing date, and organisational data are the same, the system creates a separate billing document for each Service Contract item.

Additionally, you can use the same settings for scheduled jobs as well:

  • In the Schedule Billing Creation app, this split logic can be found in the job Parameters.
  • When you activate it in the job settings and save it as a template, each scheduled run will automatically create one billing document for each Service Contract.
  • You can also apply filters for Service Contract, Sold-to Party, and Billing Date to ensure each job run only processes the items you select.

This way, you have two options:

  • Ad-hoc runs → switch ON in the Create Billing Documents app.
  • Background jobs → define once in Schedule Billing Creation and reuse via a saved template.

This guarantees you always receive one billing document per Service Contract without needing extra manual steps.

Best regards,

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Interview questions for a cost control engineer! Plea...
entry.content:
Please open per question one Thread....

 

Some transaction code:

  • S_ALR_87013611: This T-code is used for cost center analysis, specifically to view actual costs, planned costs, and variances for cost centers. It allows you to enter controlling area, fiscal year, period, and plan version to generate the report. 
     
  • KS13: This T-code is used to display cost centers. You can search for cost centers based on various criteria like cost center range, cost center group, or individual cost centers
     
  • OKKS: This T-code is used to manage controlling areas, which are a central organizational unit in CO for cost management. 
     
  • CO03: This T-code is used to display individual production orders. When displaying an order, you can access the cost analysis to view plan and actual costs, as well as G/L account information related to the order. 
     
  • S_ALR_87012993 and S_ALR_87012995: These T-codes are used to display cost analyses for multiple production orders. 
     
  • KSB1: This T-code is used to view cost center details. 
     
  • KP06: This T-code is used for planning cost center activities and budgets. 
     
  • KB11N: This T-code allows for manual cost allocation. 
     
  • KO88: This T-code is used to settle the actual costs of orders. 
     
  • KSH1: This T-code is used for creating cost center groups. 
     
  • KSH2: This T-code is used for changing cost center groups. 
     
  • KSH3: This T-code is used for displaying cost center groups.

entry.title: Re: BTP Integration Suite_Service Contract screen IF erro...
entry.content:
Hello @ISoma 

Thank you for your question regarding displaying integration errors on the Service Contract screen when using SAP BTP Integration Suite.

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, the Service Contract Save action and the BTP integration are technically decoupled. This means you cannot block the Save or display a synchronous error message in the UI if the integration fails; the integration flow runs asynchronously after the document is saved.

In fact, there are supported ways to provide clear and immediate feedback to users:

Recommended Possible Solution

Integration Status on the Contract (preferred solution)

    • Add two custom header fields: 'Service Contract Integration Status' and 'Integration Error Text
    • Your iFlow updates these fields via the Service Contract OData API:
      • On success → set status to Success.
      • On error → set status to Error and write a short error message.
    • Users can see the result directly on the Service Contract they just saved.

In-app Notification (optional solution)

    • Use Situation Handling – Extended to raise a banner or notification when the Integration Status = Error.
    • This gives the user a proactive alert in the contract screen.

Output-based Feedback (if applicable)

    • If your iFlow is activated through Output Management, the Service Contract header displays the Output Log and Status directly.

Monitoring & Support

    •  Ensure your support users have access to Message Monitoring in both S/4HANA Cloud and BTP Integration Suite.
    • ◦ Using the Service Contract number as a correlation key will assist in tracing failed messages more efficiently.

Why is this approach necessary?

In an S4 HANA Public Cloud environment, integration calls are inherently asynchronous. This design ensures system resilience and avoids blocking the process of saving business documents. The preferred method is to communicate the integration results back through the Service Contract or in-app notifications, rather than attempting to halt the save process error.

Next Steps to follow
It is recommended adding the Integration Status fields to the Service Contract and enhancing your iFlow to update these fields automatically on success or error. This allows your end-users to quickly see whether the integration was successful or failed, right on the Service Contract screen. Let us know if you need example field definitions, an API PATCH sample, or a setup guide for the Situation Handling alert.

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Issue with a simple FMS
entry.content:
Hi @joseph_antony 

The error you are encountering with your FMS formula likely stems from how the calculation expression is defined and interpreted by the (your) SQL server.

The error "Incorrect syntax near '15.000000'" suggests that your formula's syntax or data referencing might be getting passed directly into SQL in a way that is not valid.

The segment about "Shipping Types" could imply that the formula or query context involves other tables or aliases incorrectly referenced.

You can consider fixing your FMS formula by taking this approach:

Make sure you use the correct API syntax and proper referencing conventions used in the FMS expressions depending on the system (e.g., SAP Business One uses different syntax than plain SQL).

Instead of SQL-style SELECT statement, use a plain formula expression if you want SAP Business One's FMS or a similar engine to calculate it dynamically. For example:

If you need to call SQL, ensure the context is proper and parameters sanitized. Usually, FMS is for formulas, not direct SQL.

If these are UDFs in SAP Business One and you are using the FMS calculation, please ensure not to use the SELECT keyword in FMS. Use the correct field names and wrap division carefully.

Overall, this is a common challenge in promotion planning where overlapping promotions complicate demand forecasts, and careful tuning of promotion models and demand influencers is required for realistic forecasts.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Predictive Stock Transfer & Automatic Purchase Re-Order: Plant-to-Plant A2A Orchestration
entry.content:
Use-case: Predictive Stock Transfer & Automatic Purchase Re-Order (Plant-to-Plant A2A scenario driven by real-time APIs)

A fast-moving material in Plant A is kept in stock by an end-to-end, automated flow that

  1. checks forecast demand,
  2. looks for internal surplus in nearby plants, and
  3. automatically creates stock transfers or purchase requisitions as needed.

Prerequisities and needed

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud (Inventory & MRP) – On-hand stock, stock in transit, MRP items
  • SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP) – Demand forecast for FG-100 at Plant A
  • SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) – Real-time on-hand stock incl. quarantine
  • SAP Ariba – Supplier catalog and pricing for external options
  • External supplier catalog (Ariba-like) – External pricing and lead times
  • SAP Integration Suite / SAP Event Mesh – Orchestrates the end-to-end flow and publishes events

Sequence – how the APIs interact end-to-end

Step 0 – Trigger
A nightly iFlow in SAP Integration Suite (or SAP Event Mesh) starts the orchestration.

Step 1 – Demand forecast
GET /api/ibp/v1/demandplanning/forecast?material=FG-100&plant=A&weeks=4
→ Returns 1,200 pcs forecasted demand.

Step 2 – Current & projected stock in Plant A
GET /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_MATERIAL_STOCK_SRV/MaterialStock?material=FG-100&plant=A
→ 180 pcs unrestricted, 40 pcs blocked.
GET /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_MRP_COCKPIT_SRV/MrpItems?material=FG-100&plant=A
Result: confirmed receipts 600 pcs
→ Confirmed receipts 600 pcs, so net shortage = 1,200 – 180 – 600 = 420 pcs.

Step 3 – Locate surplus stock in the network
Parallel calls (one per plant):
GET /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_MATERIAL_STOCK_SRV/MaterialStock?material=FG-100&plant=B
→ 300 pcs unrestricted.
GET /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_MATERIAL_STOCK_SRV/MaterialStock?material=FG-100&plant=C
→ 250 pcs unrestricted.

Step 4 – Check ATP (available-to-transfer) incl. transit time
POST /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_ATP_CHECK_SRV/CheckAvailability
Body:

{ 
"material": "FG-100", 
"plant": "B", 
"demandQty": 300, 
"requiredDate": "2024-06-25" 
}

→ Confirms 300 pcs can be delivered by 2024-06-23.
Same for Plant C → 120 pcs available by 2024-06-24.

Step 5 – Decide cheapest internal option
Cost service (custom REST on S/4):
POST /internal/transferCost

{ 
"fromPlants": ["B","C"], 
"toPlant": "A", 
"qty": [300,120] 
}


→ Plant B has the lowest freight cost (€0.05/pc vs €0.07/pc).

Step 6 – Create stock transport order (STO)
POST /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_STOCK_TRANSPORT_ORDER_SRV/A_StockTransportOrder
Body:

{ 
"SupplyingPlant": "B", 
"ReceivingPlant": "A", 
"Material": "FG-100", 
"OrderQuantity": 300, 
"DeliveryDate": "2024-06-23" 
}

→ STO 4500012345 created.

Step 7 – Remaining uncovered quantity
Shortage after internal transfer = 420 – 300 = 120 pcs.
Call Ariba to get best external price:
GET /v2/suppliers/catalog?material=FG-100&qty=120&currency=EUR
→ Supplier S-987 offers €2.30/pc, lead time 7 days.

Step 8 – Create purchase requisition in S/4
POST /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_PURCHASEREQ_PROCESS_SRV/A_PurchaseRequisitionHeader
Body:

{ 
"Material": "FG-100", 
"Plant": "A", 
"Quantity": 120, 
"DeliveryDate": "2024-06-27", 
"SupplierHint": "S-987" 
}

→ PR 1000123456 created.

Step 9 – Notify planners
Publish event to SAP Event Mesh topic /business/plantA/stockReplenished
Payload:

{ 
"material": "FG-100", 
"sto": "4500012345", 
"pr": "1000123456", 
"status": "covered" 
}

Outcome
Plant A will receive 300 pcs from Plant B via an automatically created STO and 120 pcs via a purchase requisition with the cheapest external supplier—no manual intervention, no stock-out, and minimal freight cost.

complete code

#!/usr/bin/env python3
"""
End-to-end A2A flow:
1. Read demand forecast (IBP)
2. Check stock & MRP in Plant A
3. Search surplus stock in Plants B/C
4. Run ATP check
5. Create STO (cheapest internal)
6. Create PR for remaining qty (Ariba best price)
"""

import os, json, math
from datetime import datetime, timedelta
from dotenv import load_dotenv
from requests import Session
from requests_oauthlib import OAuth2Session
from oauthlib.oauth2 import BackendApplicationClient

load_dotenv()

# ---------- CONFIG ----------
MATERIAL = "FG-100"
PLANT_A  = "A"
PLANTS_SURPLUS = ["B", "C"]
DEMAND_WEEKS   = 4
TRANSPORT_DAYS = 2
# ----------------------------

s = Session()

# ---------- 0.  OAUTH TOKEN for S/4 ----------
def s4_token():
    url = f"{os.getenv('S4_HOST')}/oauth/token"
    r = s.post(url,
               auth=(os.getenv('S4_USER'), os.getenv('S4_PASSWORD')),
               data={'grant_type':'client_credentials'})
    r.raise_for_status()
    return r.json()['access_token']

s.headers.update({'Authorization': f"Bearer {s4_token()}"})

# ---------- 1.  IBP – demand forecast ----------
def ibp_forecast():
    url = (f"{os.getenv('S4_HOST')}/sap/opu/odata/sap/"
           f"API_DEMAND_PLANNING_SRV/DemandForecast")
    params = {
        "$filter": f"Material eq '{MATERIAL}' and Plant eq '{PLANT_A}'",
        "$select": "DemandQuantity",
        "$format": "json"
    }
    r = s.get(url, params=params)
    r.raise_for_status()
    total = sum(item['DemandQuantity'] for item in r.json()['d']['results'])
    return total

demand_qty = ibp_forecast()
print("Demand forecast:", demand_qty)

# ---------- 2.  Stock & MRP ----------
def plant_stock(plant):
    url = (f"{os.getenv('S4_HOST')}/sap/opu/odata/sap/"
           f"API_MATERIAL_STOCK_SRV/MaterialStock")
    params = {
        "$filter": f"Material eq '{MATERIAL}' and Plant eq '{plant}' and "
                   f"StorageLocation ne ''",
        "$format": "json"
    }
    r = s.get(url, params=params)
    r.raise_for_status()
    return sum(item['UnrestrictedStockQuantity']
               for item in r.json()['d']['results'])

def plant_receipts(plant):
    url = (f"{os.getenv('S4_HOST')}/sap/opu/odata/sap/"
           f"API_MRP_COCKPIT_SRV/MrpItems")
    params = {
        "$filter": f"Material eq '{MATERIAL}' and Plant eq '{plant}' and "
                   f"MrpElementCategory eq 'AR'",
        "$format": "json"
    }
    r = s.get(url, params=params)
    r.raise_for_status()
    return sum(item['Quantity'] for item in r.json()['d']['results'])

stock_A = plant_stock(PLANT_A)
receipts_A = plant_receipts(PLANT_A)
shortage = max(0, demand_qty - stock_A - receipts_A)
print("Shortage:", shortage)
if shortage == 0:
    print("No action needed.")
    exit()

# ---------- 3.  Surplus stock ----------
surplus = {}
for p in PLANTS_SURPLUS:
    surplus[p] = plant_stock(p)
print("Surplus:", surplus)

# ---------- 4.  ATP check ----------
def atp_ok(plant, qty, req_date):
    url = (f"{os.getenv('S4_HOST')}/sap/opu/odata/sap/"
           f"API_ATP_CHECK_SRV/CheckAvailability")
    body = {
        "Material": MATERIAL,
        "Plant": plant,
        "DemandQuantity": str(qty),
        "RequiredDate": req_date.isoformat()
    }
    r = s.post(url, json=body)
    r.raise_for_status()
    return r.json()['d']['ConfirmedQuantity'] == str(qty)

best_internal = None
needed = shortage
for plant, qty in surplus.items():
    take = min(qty, needed)
    req = datetime.utcnow().date() + timedelta(days=TRANSPORT_DAYS)
    if atp_ok(plant, take, req):
        best_internal = (plant, take)
        break
if best_internal:
    plant, qty = best_internal
    print(f"Best internal: {qty} from {plant}")

    # ---------- 5.  Create STO ----------
    url = (f"{os.getenv('S4_HOST')}/sap/opu/odata/sap/"
           f"API_STOCK_TRANSPORT_ORDER_SRV/A_StockTransportOrder")
    body = {
        "SupplyingPlant": plant,
        "ReceivingPlant": PLANT_A,
        "Material": MATERIAL,
        "OrderQuantity": str(qty),
        "DeliveryDate": req.isoformat()
    }
    r = s.post(url, json=body)
    r.raise_for_status()
    sto = r.json()['d']['StockTransportOrder']
    print("STO created:", sto)
    shortage -= qty

# ---------- 6.  Ariba – best external price ----------
if shortage > 0:
    client = BackendApplicationClient(client_id=os.getenv('ARIBA_CLIENT_ID'))
    oauth = OAuth2Session(client=client)
    token = oauth.fetch_token(
        token_url=os.getenv('ARIBA_TOKEN_URL'),
        client_id=os.getenv('ARIBA_CLIENT_ID'),
        client_secret=os.getenv('ARIBA_CLIENT_SECRET')
    )
    url = "https://api.ariba.com/v2/suppliers/catalog"
    params = {
        "material": MATERIAL,
        "qty": shortage,
        "currency": "EUR"
    }
    r = oauth.get(url, params=params)
    r.raise_for_status()
    best = min(r.json()['offers'], key=lambda x: float(x['price']))
    print("Best supplier:", best['supplier'], best['price'])

    # ---------- 7.  Create PR ----------
    url = (f"{os.getenv('S4_HOST')}/sap/opu/odata/sap/"
           f"API_PURCHASEREQ_PROCESS_SRV/A_PurchaseRequisitionHeader")
    body = {
        "Material": MATERIAL,
        "Plant": PLANT_A,
        "Quantity": str(shortage),
        "DeliveryDate": (datetime.utcnow().date()
                         + timedelta(days=int(best['leadtime']))).isoformat(),
        "SupplierHint": best['supplier']
    }
    r = s.post(url, json=body)
    r.raise_for_status()
    pr = r.json()['d']['PurchaseRequisition']
    print("PR created:", pr)

print("Flow finished.")

entry.title: Re: DMEE XML File truncated after S/4HANA 2023 upgrade
entry.content:
Hi Alessandro, thanks for the follow-up. After the S/4HANA 2023 upgrade, CGI XML formats (e.g., DE_CGI_XML_CT) run on DMEEX, not classic DMEE. In DMEEX the classic BAdI DMEE_BADI_01 is deprecated (2023 FPS2) and removed in 2025, so it will not trigger.

What to use now: Implement Enhancement Spot ES_DMEEX --> BAdI DMEE_OUTPUT_POSTPROCESSING and set filters TREE_TYPE = PAYM and TREE_ID = <your mapping ID>. Put a breakpoint or simple marker in method MODIFY_OUTPUT, then re-run the download (F110/FDTA). If the breakpoint hits, you’re on the correct hook to adjust the XML.

If your tree is still in DMEE, open it in DMEEX and use the built-in migration assistant, since DMEE config is disabled from S/4HANA 2025 and runtime is planned to be retired later.

Sources:

 

  • Simplification List for SAP S/4HANA 2023 (FPS3)

  • SAP Learning: Creating Custom Post-processing of the Output Payment File

entry.title: Enhancing Security in SAP Cloud Transport Management in SAP BTP - 1
entry.content:
About Me

Hare Krishna 🙏 I am an SAP BTP Cloud Architect sharing practical insights, solutions, and real-world experiences from the SAP ecosystem.

About the Blog

Node-Based Privileges for Granular Control

In modern cloud-driven operations, safeguarding production environments is non-negotiable. The latest enhancements in SAP Cloud Transport Management (cTMS) reinforce this with more precise access control, ensuring that sensitive transport operations stay firmly in the right hands.

What Changed — A Shift to Node-Specific Role Privileges

Traditionally, default roles in cTMS endowed users with broad-level access—often across all transport nodes. This "all-or-nothing" model presented a risk: one user could inadvertently or deliberately affect both development and production landscapes.

SAP has introduced node-specific privileges, enabling the assignment of roles tied to specific transport nodes only. In other words, you can empower a user to perform imports on the DEV node while blocking access to PRD—enforcing a principle of least privilege and securing production access by design.

Why Node-Based Access Matters

  1. Robust Access Governance
    By refining permissions at the node level, you can provide users only with the exact access they need—nothing more. This minimizes risk and helps enforce your internal controls effectively.

  2. Secure Production Environments
    Often, production subaccounts may contain highly sensitive data or critical business logic. Restricting transport permissions ensures that only trusted roles can push changes to production—reducing accidental errors or unauthorized updates.

  3. Cleaner Audit Trails
    When transports are performed, cTMS logs user actions with timestamps and node contexts. Node-based permissions make it easier to trace "who did what and where," boosting transparency and accountability.

  4. Better Separation of Duties
    Node-level restrictions support clean operational delineation—developers can be limited to DEV/QA, while release managers or operations teams handle PRD imports. This aligns with governance best practices.

How to Implement Node-Based Security in cTMS

Step 1: Define Role Templates and Node-Specific Roles

Start by leveraging SAP’s role templates, such as ImportOperator and TransportOperator, which serve as foundations for node-based roles. Create custom roles from these templates and attach node attributes to define the scope of operation.

Note:

  • When adding attributes to roles, it isn't validated that the transport node names actually exist in your transport landscape.

  • When you delete a transport node, you must manually update the corresponding role if necessary.

  • If you don’t add any attributes to a role, this grants unrestricted access to all nodes.

  • If a user has both restricted and unrestricted roles assigned, the restricted role takes effect.

Step 2: Build Role Collections

Group these node-specific roles into meaningful role collections—for example, “DEV-Importer,” “QA-Transporter,” or “PRD-Approver.” Role collections streamline user assignment.

Step 3: Assign Role Collections to Users

Within the SAP BTP cockpit under Security, assign the appropriate role collections to users who require node-specific transport capabilities.

Step 4: Conduct Import Operations

When users import transport requests, their permissions are evaluated against their assigned node-specific role collections—ensuring that only authorized users can act on particular nodes.

Real-World Example

Using the ImportOperator and TransportOperator templates, admins can custom-configure node-specific roles, assigning them per node and granting access only to designated users for each node. 

Current Architecture:

 

Define Role Templates and Node-Specific Roles

Create 2 roles using Import operator Role template: Non_Prod_Transport_Operator Role and Prod_Transport_Operator Role

Click on Create Role

Enter Role Name
In Configure Attributes: enter the exact node names to restrict this privilege to specific nodes assigned in this step

Select the Role collection from non Prod, Click on Finish after providing all the details

Similarly Create Role from Production Node
To restrict privileges to Production Node, Provide the Production Node name in Configure Attributes

Select Role collection for this role template

Click On Finish

Assign the Non Production Role collection to NonProd User

\

Assign the Production Role collection to Prod User

Login With Prod user to check: If received all the access to production node and no access to other nodes:

Got all the access to Prod Node

However ImportAll permission to Non Prod nodes (Just stay with me - we will fix it in few seconds).

Note on Role Restrictions

  • The TmsNodesTransportOperator attribute restricts authorizations only for TransportOperator tasks, but not for ImportOperator tasks that are also part of this role.

  • To restrict ImportOperator tasks as well, create a custom role using the ImportOperator template and assign the TmsNodesImport attribute.

  • This setup allows you, for example, to give a user permission to perform imports in all transport nodes, while limiting their ability to perform TransportOperator tasks to only specific transport nodes.

 

Create another role to restrict the privilege of import operator role to specific node

You can also provide a dummy node or virtual node or anything - this will make sure import all privilege will be removed from all other nodes except this one.

If you notice i have provided dev node, it will restrict the privilege to dev node(if a node exist with this name) else it will just make sure privileges of import all will be gone from all other nodes.

Now assign this permission to Prod User - This will make sure import all permission is removed.

We can see that permission is not visible now for prod user to any non prod nodes.

Similar issue is there for Non Prod user as well.

Now think of a scenario where No access is granted for non production user in Prod node however Import_all is granted, this can be a serious problem. Let's fix it for Non_Prod user as well.

Correct permissions in Non Production nodes.

However permission of import_all is granted in Prod node. Let's fix this

Assign the restrict import operator role collection created in previous steps to non prod user now.

Required permissions are intact in Non Prod nodes

 

ImportAll permission is removed from Prod node (Worked as expected)

 

Final Thoughts: Embrace Granular, Secure Transport Processes

The migration from coarse-grained default roles to node-based authorization is a strong leap forward in transport security for SAP BTP environments. By adopting these practices, you:

  • Minimize exposure of production systems

  • Align with compliance and audit requirements

  • Enhance separation of duties across functions

SAP’s node-level restriction model is a powerful tool for organizations aiming to strengthen their DevOps workflows while keeping production environments tightly controlled.

What’s Next?

In the next part of this blog series, we’ll focus on authentication and authorization enhancements—covering Single Sign-On (SSO) for UI access, automated role assignment with IAS/IDMS groups, and replacing Basic Authentication with OAuth2Password for destinations.

Stay tuned to learn how these features further strengthen your cTMS security!

entry.title: Re: How Can We Consume Standard APIs With Business Users...
entry.content:
Hello @ItsMeGopi 

Standard APIs are accessible via communication setups that require users to authenticate in the S4 Public Cloud. Business users, such as employees or partners, cannot authenticate directly against these APIs.

If a business user needs to consume or work with API data, there are two supported approaches.

Indirect consumption via Fiori apps or custom UI

    • Business users access data through Fiori apps or extensions built with Key-User Extensibility or SAP Build Apps.
    • These front-ends call the API in the background using a communication user.

Delegated access through Identity Authentication / Identity Provisioning

    • For scenarios where business users need to call APIs themselves from external apps, you must configure OAuth 2.0 with SAP Cloud Identity Services.
    • Here, the business user authenticates with their corporate identity; the system exchanges the token and calls the API on their behalf.
    • This setup is supported only for APIs that allow OAuth2SAMLBearerAssertion or OAuth2Password flows.

Key point:

  • APIs are never consumed directly with a normal business user ID.
  • Either you use a technical communication user, or you enable OAuth with IAS so that the API call is technically authenticated but mapped to the business user context.

Business users cannot access APIs directly with their own IDs. Instead, use communication users technical or set up OAuth with SAP Identity Authentication to enable business identities to trigger API calls securely.

With regards

Chuma

 

SAP Documentation References

  • SAP Help Portal: Communication Management in S/4HANA Cloud
  • SAP Help Portal: OAuth 2.0 authentication in S/4HANA Cloud APIs
  • SAP Business Accelerator Hub: API Hub – SAP S/4HANA Cloud APIs

entry.title: Enhancing Security in SAP Cloud Transport Management in SAP BTP - 2
entry.content:
About Me

Hare Krishna 🙏 I am an SAP BTP Cloud Architect sharing practical insights, solutions, and real-world experiences from the SAP ecosystem.

About the Blog

In the first part of this blog series, we explored role-based restrictions for SAP Cloud Transport Management (cTMS). In this second part, we focus on security enhancements in authentication and authorization that help organizations safeguard their transport operations.

We’ll look at three areas:

  1. Establishing SSO for UI access

  2. Role collection automation with IDMS groups

  3. Replacing Basic Authentication with OAuth2Password for destinations

1. Establishing SSO for UI Access

The first step in strengthening security is ensuring that administrators and operators (users performing import/export operations) access cTMS only through Single Sign-On (SSO).

  • Configure your subaccount to use IAS (or another corporate Identity Provider) as the primary IdP.

  • Disable the “Allow Identity Provider Login” checkbox for S-User IDs. This ensures users are not prompted to select an IdP at login and are automatically redirected to your corporate IdP.

  • Result: Direct SSO-based login, eliminating the risk of S-User credentials being used to access the UI.

✅Benefit: Centralized authentication, no fallback to S-Users, and seamless enterprise login for all UI-based operations.

Real Life Examples

In this scenario, i am using IAS as Identity provider. You can use IAS as proxy to any IDMS (Microsft Azure AD etc).

Establish trust with IAS tenant by clicking on Establish trust on top right corner.

Make sure you disable the "Available for User logon" option for SUSER ID. This will make sure it don't prompt users to select IDP. You can keep it enabled if you want to give option to users to login with SUSER as well.

Now Once user is setup in IAS, and required permissions are provided in BTP Subaccount,  Click on Go-To Application.

Enter the IAS UserID and Password - user which is setup for Cloud TMS login with required permissions

After successful login, you will be redirected to Cloud TMS screen.

 

2. Automating Role Assignments with IDMS Groups

Managing role collections directly for individual users can be error-prone and time-consuming. Instead, SAP recommends using Identity Directory (IDMS) groups to streamline access provisioning.

  • Map IDMS user groups to role collections in the BTP subaccount.

  • When a user is added to or removed from an IDMS group, the corresponding role collections are automatically assigned or revoked.

  • This eliminates manual steps, reduces the risk of incorrect assignments, and aligns user access with enterprise identity governance.

✅Benefit: Faster onboarding, reduced manual errors, and consistent access governance across your cTMS landscape.

Real Life Examples

We will be using IAS as identity provider and IAS groups for mapping. (Any IDMS groups like Azure AD can also be used for mapping). Let's see how it's done.

 Make sure IAS Application for subaccount is set to send Groups as attributes to BTP Subaccount in OIDC token

Create the Group for example ProdAccess

Assign the ProdUser to the group which we will use for authentication

Perform the Role collection mapping with IAS Group in BTP Cockpit. Make sure the Select the correct identity provider

Now perform the login with ProdUser

Login was successful, All the required privileges are automatically assigned to user

Prod permissions are assigned

Import all restrictions are also assigned properly

OIDC token contains the Groups attributes:

3. Moving from Basic Authentication to OAuth2Password

For backend communication (system-to-system), destinations in BTP must also be secured. Traditionally, Basic Authentication with S-User credentials was used, but this approach is less secure.

The recommended method is OAuth2Password with a technical user in IAS.

Steps:

  • Create a technical user in the Platform SSO IAS (the same IAS that manages subaccount logins).
  • Configure the destination in your subaccount to use OAuth2Password.
  • Add the origin property so the token request is routed to the Platform SSO IAS.

Enter the user and password as techincal userid and password created in previous step. Origin key should be of the Custom identity provider for Platform Users:

Origin key:

Destination:

  • Assign the required roles to this IAS technical user for the cTMS org/space.

⚠️Critical Note: Only the Platform SSO IAS (the one configured for platform-level SSO) can be used for this technical user. Other IAS tenants in your landscape cannot be used here. If you attempt to use another IAS, the destination may still validate during “Check Connection” but transport operations will fail (401 errors) at runtime.

✅Benefit: Removes reliance on personal or shared S-User credentials, strengthens system-to-system security, and enforces centralized authentication.

Conclusion

By implementing these three measures, you can significantly strengthen the security posture of SAP Cloud Transport Management:

  • Enforcing SSO for UI access ensures no S-User logins are used for administration.

  • IDMS group-to-role mapping simplifies and automates user provisioning.

  • Transitioning to OAuth2Password secures backend destinations with technical users in IAS.

Together, these enhancements reduce risks, improve compliance, and streamline secure operations across your transport landscape.

entry.title: Clear Salary outside HireDate and TerminationDate ranges, and calculate per day salary
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I need to clear salary, when Date(YYYYMM) dimensions, has values outside of HireDate(YYYY-MM-DD) and TerminationDate(YYYY-MM-DD) dimensions, if the month matches I need to calculate per day salary and calculate accordingly.

I have recreated a similar Test model with similar data and structure, here is my code and approach:

CONFIG.HIERARCHY.INCLUDE_MEMBERS_NOT_IN_HIERARCHY = [d/Account], [d/CostCenter], [d/Emp_Status], [d/Employee], [d/LegalEntity], [d/Location]
CONFIG.GENERATE_UNBOOKED_DATA = ON

MEMBERSET [d/Measures] = "Amount_LC"  // Scope to the specific measure
MEMBERSET [d/Account] = "ACC_017"     // Filter to the specific account
MEMBERSET [d/DataSource] = "DS_PAYROLL"
MEMBERSET [d/Employee] = (BASEMEMBER([d/Employee].[h/EmpStatus], "ACTIVE", "TERMINATED", "TO_BE_HIRED", "INACTIVE"))

// Vectorized conditional assignments using IF-THEN-ENDIF
IF DATEDIFF([d/HireDate], [d/Date], "MONTH") < 0 OR DATEDIFF([d/Date], [d/TerminationDate], "MONTH") < 0 THEN
    DATA([d/Account] = "ACC_017", [d/Measures] = "Amount_LC", [d/DataSource] = "DS_PAYROLL") = 0
ELSE
    IF DATEDIFF([d/HireDate], [d/Date], "MONTH") = 0 AND DATEDIFF([d/Date], [d/TerminationDate], "MONTH") = 0 THEN
        DATA([d/Account] = "ACC_017", [d/Measures] = "Amount_LC", [d/DataSource] = "DS_PAYROLL") = 
            (DATEDIFF([d/HireDate], [d/TerminationDate], "DAY") + 1) / DAYSINMONTH([d/Date]) * RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "Amount_LC")
    ELSE
        IF DATEDIFF([d/HireDate], [d/Date], "MONTH") = 0 THEN
            DATA([d/Account] = "ACC_017", [d/Measures] = "Amount_LC", [d/DataSource] = "DS_PAYROLL") = 
                DATEDIFF([d/HireDate], [d/Date], "DAY") / DAYSINMONTH([d/Date]) * RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "Amount_LC")
        ELSE
            IF DATEDIFF([d/Date], [d/TerminationDate], "MONTH") = 0 THEN
                DATA([d/Account] = "ACC_017", [d/Measures] = "Amount_LC", [d/DataSource] = "DS_PAYROLL") = 
                    (DATEDIFF([d/Date], [d/TerminationDate], "DAY") + 1) / DAYSINMONTH([d/Date]) * RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "Amount_LC")
            ELSE
                DATA([d/Measures] = "Amount_LC") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "Amount_LC")  // Full month
            ENDIF
        ENDIF
    ENDIF
ENDIF

For this code, I got "Too many member combination errors", so please help me if I can take any other approach or ways to correct this. I have avoided FOREACH because of performance issues

entry.title: Re: Custom KPI Cards in SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2, SAP Enterprise Service Management
entry.content:
@Kushal--Gupta Thanks for sharing this. Great to see that It's finally possible to configure the KPI cards based on predefined filters. 

Earlier way of doing such a simple exercise was quite a lot of pain for customer, but as they say, better late than never.

entry.title: HCM Migration from ECC to S/4HANA or Another ERP: Functionality Limitations vs. SuccessFactors
entry.content:
At my company, we use HCM in ECC and intend to migrate to S/4HANA, but the company is considering migrating to another ERP.

The reason for this change is that HCM doesn't offer certain services, such as employee vacation management, employee time-clock requests, a paycheck app, and development/training management through the ERP.

Does anyone know if HCM offers these features? Or only SuccessFactors?
